descriptionSet.description: A view of a village atop a hill with colourful houses with green roofs. Trees and plants can be seen as well all over the hill. Streets and paths criss- cross the hill.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: A view of a village atop a hill with colourful houses with green roofs. Trees and plants can be seen as well all over the hill. Streets and paths criss- cross the hill. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: A typical feature of the hill station postcards is that they often show colonial establishments such as military cantonments and churches. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: An eye-catching view of the buildings constructed on the hills and in the lap of valley. As the buildings and pathways criss-cross, beautiful geometrical patterns emerge, enhancing visual appeal of the scene. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: These establishments occupy the same place in the picture that a handsome old castle or a grand ruin would occupy in a picturesque landscape painting from the metropole. This transformation of a castle in the metropole to a cantonment or church in the colonies is more than just the monumentalizing of these institutions as colonial achievements. This transformation is related to the role of transplantation in the picturesque aesthetic. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)
related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" (gs)
related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-16, Tasveer Ghar essay (gs)
